channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Did My Cat Just Hit On Me? An Adventure in Pet Translation
item.description: Entrepreneurs are aiming to put A.I.-powered pet translation tools into our pockets.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: A Long-Lost Branch of the Nile Helped in Building Egypt’s Pyramids
item.description: A new study confirms a long-held theory that builders used the river to transport the heavy blocks that comprise the ancient wonders.
item.dc:creator: Jack Tamisiea
item.media:description: The Pyramids of Khufu, left, and Khafre looming in Egypt. Scientists reconstructed the 8,000-year rise and fall of the Khufu Branch of the Nile River, a tributary no longer in existence.

item.title: How ‘the Most Vicious, Horrible Animal Alive’ Became a YouTube Star
item.description: Joseph Carter, known to his online followers as the Mink Man, trains feisty carnivores to rid canals and urban river banks of midsize pests.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang and Kim Raff
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times

item.title: The Animal Translators
item.description: Scientists are using machine learning to eavesdrop on naked mole rats, fruit bats, crows and whales — and to communicate back.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Naked mole rats live in large, underground colonies and have an elaborate vocal repertoire.

item.title: Why NASA Is Going Back to the Moon
item.description: The agency is set to launch a massive rocket on Monday, kicking off a return to Earth’s closest neighbor after many scientists and policymakers had once moved on.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: The moon, one scientist said, “is the best place in the solar system to study the origin and evolution of planets in the solar system.”

item.title: Octopuses Don’t Have Backbones — or Rights
item.description: As cephalopods become more important in neuroscience and other fields, scientists and welfare advocates seek to give the smart animals the same protections as mice and monkeys.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Preston
item.media:description: More octopuses and other cephalopods are being used in labs, where federal animal welfare laws do not apply to them.

item.title: Secret Data, Tiny Islands and a Quest for Treasure on the Ocean Floor
item.description: Mining in parts of the Pacific Ocean was meant to benefit poor countries, but an international agency gave a Canadian company access to prized seabed sites with metals crucial to the green energy revolution.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times

item.title: Some Monkeys Use Stone Tools for Pleasure, Study Suggests
item.description: Self-pleasure, that is.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: To Prevent a Martian Plague, NASA Needs to Build a Very Special Lab
item.description: The likelihood is low that bringing rocks to Earth from the red planet will make us sick, but the space agency isn’t taking any chances.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Scoles

item.title: US Life Expectancy Falls Again in ‘Historic’ Setback
item.description: The decline during the pandemic is the sharpest in nearly 100 years, hitting American Indian and Native Alaskan communities particularly hard.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: A patient who died of Covid was removed from an I.C.U. in Cleveland, Ohio.

item.title: Toxic Red Tide Kills ‘Uncountable’ Numbers of Fish in the Bay Area
item.description: A harmful algal bloom in the San Francisco Bay is killing fish, sharks and stingrays. Some are washing ashore.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:description: A dead fish floats in Lake Merritt, on Monday, in Oakland, Calif.

item.title: NASA Plans to Retry Its Moon Rocket Launch on Saturday
item.description: After scrubbing its launch of the Artemis I mission on Monday, NASA said it hoped to resolve an engine problem by a second launch window this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: The NASA moon rocket for the Artemis I mission standing on a launchpad at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Tuesday.

item.title: Humpback Whales Pass Their Songs Across Oceans
item.description: Whales share songs from Australia to Ecuador, scientists have found, suggesting a remarkably fast cultural evolution.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: A humpback whale breaching in waters near Esmeraldas, Ecuador. Whales in Australia were found to be passing their songs to others in French Polynesia, which in turn gave songs to whales in Ecuador.

item.title: Paxlovid Cuts Covid Deaths Among Older People, Israeli Study Finds
item.description: Among patients under 65, however, the drug made little difference in hospitalization or death rates.
item.dc:creator: Roni Rabin
item.media:description: According to the new Israeli study, the medication was highly effective when administered to individuals 65 and over.

item.title: In Brazil, the Last Member of an Isolated Indigenous Tribe Dies
item.description: Known as the “Man of the Hole,” the last member of an Indigenous group was found dead this month, marking the first recorded disappearance of an isolated tribe in the country.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance and André Spigariol
item.media:description: A still image from a video provided by the Brazilian government showing one of the huts built by the “Man of the Hole” in Rondônia State in 2018.

item.title: Deadly Floods Devastate an Already Fragile Pakistan
item.description: More than 1,100 have died as record monsoon rains inundate the country, washing away bridges, roads and crop fields. Much of Pakistan is underwater.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Raymond Zhong and Ihsanullah Tipu Mehsud
item.media:description: Army troops evacuated people from a flood-hit area in Rajanpur, Punjab district, Pakistan, on Saturday.

item.title: Greenland’s Melting Ice Sheet Could Raise Sea Levels by Nearly a Foot: Study
item.description: The study reached a more drastic conclusion than earlier assessments in part because it used a different method to gauge ice loss.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:description: An iceberg in Baffin Bay near Pituffik, Greenland, in July.

item.title: NASA Moon Launch Delay: What to Know About the Artemis Rocket
item.description: The mission’s managers will complete assessments before announcing whether the rocket could try to launch again this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang and Christine Chung
item.media:description: The Artemis I mission on the launchpad at Kennedy Space Center, at sunrise on Monday.

item.title: How and When to Watch NASA’s Giant Rocket Launch to the Moon
item.description: Here’s what you need to know about Artemis I and the launch of the Space Launch System and Orion capsule.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: The Space Launch System and Orion capsule on Friday. The rocket is scheduled to lift off for the uncrewed Artemis I mission on Monday.

item.title: Cloud Wars: Mideast Rivalries Rise Along a New Front
item.description: As climate change makes the region hotter and drier, the U.A.E. is leading the effort to squeeze more rain out of the clouds, and other countries are rushing to keep up.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and Bryan Denton

item.title: Fall Vaccination Campaign Will Bring New Shots, Worse Access
item.description: Updated Covid vaccines, expected soon after Labor Day, were designed to thwart Omicron variants. But money to distribute them has dried up.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:credit: Aaron Nesheim for The New York Times
item.media:description: Coral Garner helping families fill out a survey on childhood vaccinations at a back-to-school event in Minneapolis, Minn. She had organized Covid vaccine clinics before losing her contract in June.

item.title: Ashes of Nichelle Nichols, Lieutenant Uhura From “Star Trek,” to Be Launched Into Deep Space
item.description: The ashes of Ms. Nichols, who played Lieutenant Uhura on “Star Trek,” will be on a Vulcan rocket to be launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., later this year.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: The United Launch Alliance Vulcan rocket will carry a portion of Ms. Nichols’s ashes, as well as cremated remains, DNA samples and messages of greetings.

item.title: ‘The Best Tool We Have’ for Self-Harming and Suicidal Teens
item.description: Studies indicate that dialectical behavior therapy offers greater benefits than more generalized therapy. But treatment is intensive, and expensive.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel
item.media:credit: Anastasiia Sapon for The New York Times
item.media:description: “There’s no medication for suicidal behavior,” said Michele Berk, a psychologist at Stanford University. “The patient needs to learn other behavioral skills that the medication does not teach you.”

item.title: A Child Has Monkeypox in New York City, Officials Say
item.description: Federal officials are “cautiously optimistic” as monkeypox cases decline, even as health officials announced the first pediatric case in New York City.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein and Noah Weiland
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A vaccination campaign for those most at risk, mainly, men who have sex with men, has helped tamp down a monkeypox epidemic.

item.title: This Is Not the Monkeypox That Doctors Thought They Knew
item.description: The patients turning up at clinics often have a range of symptoms that are not typical of the infection. Some of the infected seem to have no symptoms at all.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: KC Nwakalor for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Dimie Ogoina, author of a study of monkeypox cases in Nigeria that documented unusual new symptoms. “If what is happening in Europe and the global North had not happened, I don’t think that paper would be discussed,” he said.

item.title: Here Are the Challenges Ahead for California’s Ban on Gas Cars
item.description: Enforcement could be complex and legal challenges are likely. But ultimately, experts say, success or failure will depend on steady supply and buyers’ appetite.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times
item.media:description: California’s policy will reverberate across the nation.

item.title: E.P.A. to Designate PFAS, or ‘Forever Chemicals,’ as Hazardous
item.description: A proposed rule would require companies to report spills of two toxic chemicals that have been linked to cancer.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: PFAS chemicals have been found in a range of products including carpets, waterproof clothing and food packaging, including some microwave popcorn bags.

item.title: How to Get Heart Patients to Take Their Pills? Give Them Just One.
item.description: Patients given a combination “polypill” after a heart attack were more likely to stick to their regimens, researchers reported.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Georgia Kirkos/McMaster University, via Associated Press
item.media:description: People who were given a three-in-one polypill within six months of a heart attack were more likely to stick to their drug regimens and had fewer cardiovascular events than those receiving the usual assortment of pills.

item.title: Moderna Sues Pfizer and BioNTech Over Covid Vaccine Technology
item.description: Two lawsuits filed in Massachusetts and Germany claim the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine violated Moderna’s mRNA patents.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Moderna said Pfizer and BioNTech had infringed on patents filed between 2010 and 2016.

item.title: The Dugong ‘Sea Cow’ Has Vanished from China’s Waters, Study Says
item.description: The study said the dugong, a vegetarian mammal that ranges across Asia and Africa, has essentially vanished from the country’s coastline.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A dugong in the lagoons of New Caledonia, east of Australia. The species has become the first large vertebrate to go “functionally extinct” in China’s coastal waters.

item.title: Webb Telescope Sees a Carbon Dioxide Atmosphere Way Out There
item.description: WASP-39b, a distant world with a mass equivalent to Saturn’s, is the first exoplanet known to harbor the gas.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: NASA, ESA, CSA, and L. Hustak (STScI)
item.media:description: An artist’s depiction of the hot gas giant WASP-39b, some 700 light-years from Earth.

item.title: White House Pushes Journals to Drop Paywalls on Publicly Funded Research
item.description: The policy, hailed by researchers as “transformational,” will be fully in place by 2026 and make publicly financed research available immediately at no cost.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.category: Office of Science and Technology Policy
item.media:credit: Amanda Andrade-Rhoades for The New York Times
item.media:description: “There should be no delay or barrier between the American public and the returns on their investments in research,” said Alondra Nelson, director of the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy.

item.title: Psilocybin Therapy Sharply Reduces Excessive Drinking, Small Study Shows
item.description: Researchers said the results offered promise to the millions of Americans with alcohol use disorder.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.category: New York University Langone Medical Center
item.media:credit: John Karsten Moran/NYU Langone Health, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A psilocybin capsule used in a study, published Wednesday, that helped heavy drinkers cut back or quit entirely.

item.title: Will Your Dog Get Dementia? A Large New Study Offers Clues.
item.description: The risk of canine cognitive dysfunction, a.k.a. “doggy dementia,” is far greater in dogs who don’t get enough exercise, researchers found. Their risk factors echo some in humans, whose homes they share.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Heather Ainsworth for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dante, an 11-year-old Bernese mountain dog who has been diagnosed with canine cognitive dysfunction, at Cass Park in Ithaca, N.Y. on Wednesday.

item.title: Spiders Are Caught in a Global Web of Misinformation
item.description: Researchers looked at thousands of spider news stories to study how sensationalized information spreads. Their findings could be broadly applicable.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang

item.title: California to Ban the Sale of New Gasoline Cars
item.description: The decision, to take effect by 2035, will very likely speed a wider transition to electric vehicles because many other states follow California’s standards.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport, Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
item.media:description: The San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge. At least 12 other states are already in line to adopt California’s zero-emissions vehicle mandate.
